TextView.android:text: A fraction represents a part of a whole. we typically write fractions as two numbers separated by a line, sometimes one above the other, sometimes at an angle such as ½, 3/4, etc., consisting of a numerator (the top number) and a denominator (bottom number). The numerator represents the number of parts, and the denominator indicating how many equal parts make up a whole. An example is 3/4, in which the numerator, 3, tells us that the fraction represents 3 equal parts, and the denominator, 4, tells us that 4 parts equal a whole.

Dividing the numerator and denominator of a fraction by the same non-zero number will also yield an equivalent fraction. This is called reducing or simplifying the fraction. A simple fraction in which the numerator and denominator are coprime that is, the only positive integer that goes into both the numerator and denominator evenly is 1 is said to be irreducible, in lowest terms, or in simplest terms. For example, 3/9 is not in lowest terms because both 3 and 9 can be exactly divided by 3. In contrast, 3/8 is in lowest terms—the only positive integer that goes into both 3 and 8 evenly is 1.

The first rule of addition is that only like quantities can be added; you must first convert to like quantities. you must have the same denominator for exsamble 1/2 and 1/4 have diiferent denominators, so you have to muntiply the numerator and denominator by a number to get the same denominator. multiply 1/2 by 2 to get 2/4 now add the numerators to get (2+1)/4 = 3/4.

The first rule of Subtracting is that only like quantities can be added; you must first convert to like quantities. you must have the same denominator for exsamble 1/2 and 1/4 have diiferent denominators, so you have to muntiply the numerator and denominator by a number to get the same denominator. multiply 1/2 by 2 to get 2/4 now Subtract the numerators to get (2-1)/4 = 1/4.

To multiply fractions, multiply the numerators and multiply the denominators. A short cut for multiplying fractions is called cancellation. In effect, we reduce the answer to lowest terms during multiplication. A two is a common factor in both the numerator of the left fraction and the denominator of the right and is divided out of both. Three is a common factor of the left denominator and right numerator and is divided out of both.

To divide a fraction by a whole number, you may either divide the numerator by the number, if it goes evenly into the numerator, or multiply the denominator by the number. For example, 10/3 divided by 5 equals 2/3 and also equals 10/(3X5) = 10/15, which reduces to 2/3. To divide a fraction by a fraction , multiply by the reciprocal of that fraction. 1/2 divided by 3/4 = (1X4)/(2X3) = 4/6 = 2/3.
